title: Phillips ‘New Now’ Offers a Mix of Masters and Lesser-Known Artists
text:
Text size

Over 220 lots, comprising of a mixture of works of art by 20th-century masters alongside auction newcomers, will be offered at Phillips’ first New York sale of the season on Sept. 24.

Titled “New Now,” the sale includes pieces by Keith Haring, Sam Francis, Louise Nevelson, Yinka Shonibare, and Yayoi Kusama, as well as pieces from several prominent private collections.

“We will offer works from both blue-chip artists, whose markets are time-tested, and those whose works are just being sold on the secondary market for the first time, offering collectors a wonderful opportunity to build their collections with interesting and exciting material,” said Sam Mansour, head of the sale, in a statement.

The star lot is Keith Haring’s Untitled (Three Dancing Figures), Version A, estimated to sell for between $600,000 and $800,000. The aluminum sculpture was executed in 1989—just one year before Haring’s death—depicting a group of uniquely hued, faceless figures circled in energetic movement.

The sculpture is from an anonymous, private collector, who is also offering George Rickey’s Space Churn with Cams VI (estimate: $70,000-$100,000), Tom Wesselman's Belt Still Life (estimate: $30,000-$50,000), and F Friedel Dzubas' Far Land (estimate: $40,000-$60,000)

Sixteen works from the collection of Miles and Shirley Fiterman will also be included in the sale. Miles Fiterman, who died in 2004 at age 84, was the founder of lumber company Miles Homes, which sold to the Insilco Corp. in 1972. Shirley Fiterman still lives with much of the collection—one of the most comprehensive collections of works by American post-war artists—they amassed together since the 1960s.

The couple were benefactors and board members of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art and the Tel Aviv Museum, and established the Miles and Shirley Fiterman Gallery at the Minneapolis Institute of Art. In 1993, they donated $30 million to the Borough of Manhattan Community College, which named an office building after them.

E VIII by Sam Francis Courtesy of Phillips

One of the highlights from the Fitermans’ collection is Sam Francis’ EVIII, which is expected to fetch up to $450,000. The painting is being offered for the first time at auction, having remained in the Fitermans’ collection for 45 years, Phillips said.

Completed in 1971, the work shows a vast negative space across a large-scale canvas with clouds of colors to the corners, representing Francis’ love of color, light, and travel.

Also offered from The Miles and Shirley Fiterman collection are Frank Stella's Narwola II, 1971, with a high estimate of $350,000; A Alexander Calder's The Pub, 1972; and Jim Dine’s A Boot Bench #1, 1965, with the latter two having a high estimate of $60,000.

Phillips sold part of the property from the Fitermans’ collection in the spring.

Separately, Phillips will debut its first ever online-only design auction, featuring works from the Quico Collection, which is mostly comprised of Nordic and Scandinavian Design, from Sept. 16-25. Quico is a shop in Harajuku, Tokyo, selling and exhibiting high-end furniture, decorative art, bags, and shoes.
description: The auction house’s first New York sale of the season will feature works by Keith Haring, Sam Francis, and dozens of others
